commentBody:
Nice to see C.C.
Friday fun, but
I found it a bit EZ.

YMMV.
I done did this puzz
Loved this breezy Friday puzzle and learned a couple of new fun facts in the process.  Not surprising, given the talented constructor.
So much fun! This has been a great week. I think I liked this one the best. I just had to keep plugging away. Thanks!
Some very nice tricky clues.
“Top speeds” and “no hit games” on Opening Day feels blasphemous… good puzzle though!

"What'd do you think of the worker bee's speech?"
"It was okay. Just filled with a lot of buzzwords."

("Yeah, but you drone on yourself.")

This was a tasty puzzle, what with WASABIMAYO and POBOYS.  An oyster POBOY with WASABIMAYO might even be good.  There was a little bit of everything in the puzzle from gentle misdirections, to fresh fill, and a modicum of general knowledge questions.  I liked BEERSNOBS for those wise on weizenbocks and NOMAS for Spanish uncle (thanks Roberto Duran).  I also got a smile out of seeing AWOKE above ABED. 

I admit I had a bit of a pang seeing DELMAR in the puzzle.  My wife was living in Carmel Valley SanDiego, adjacent to DELMAR when we started dating, and although she moved east when we got married, she kept her townhouse and rented it for 10 years.  Then in 2021 she repossessed her place and fixed it up. We experimented with bicoastal living until 2024, when she decided the back and forth was too taxing and that she preferred to be back in the east full time.  Although I am a life long easterner, I miss California, and spent many happy hours in DELMAR, walking the beach, or hiking in the Torrey Pines reserve, and even occasionally going to the races at the DELMAR  track.

I can’t figure out why they don’t call it Kayak Polo…

CANOE?
Very fun little Friday. While not too hard, terribly enjoyable.

No junk in the grid? NOHITGAMES — technically correct, but no one has ever, ever said that. NOHITTERS is what you’re looking for. SAWSUP? What does that even mean? Has anyone ever, in the history of English, said they “sawed up” a piece of wood?

Nice one! Smiling at all the solving honey in each filled square! Now for a deserved apiarist - Beeunas noches, my crossword compadres. Buzz, why don't you play us out . . . https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=hnVnrn4zVF4

Tough one. As a point of personal privilege, I'm in Boston this week for Figure Skating Worlds at the TD Garden. At the bottom of the escalator is a statue of a hockey player I only know from crossword puzzles...

Would have found 25A easier had it just been SAWS. I’ve sawed through things, don’t think I’ve ever sawed anything up. I feel like if I were to saw up some wood, there’d be wood at the end but not at the beginning.

I just loved [Spanish uncle?] as NOMAS.  The longer it takes for me to get it, the more rewarding it is.

That's just inspired cluing.  

Really liked the rest of the puzzle, too.  I've never heard of CANOEPOLO, but I would assume it's very tough on the horses, trying to maintain their balance in the canoe with a rider on their back.

Marvelous animals, those horses.

I wish I was a horse.

Some juicy clues to saw up with my pen. My mom is Scuba Divering in the Phillipines, but not canoe poloing in kayaks. I like the bee dance but agree it should beee no hitter. Relatively easy, nice Friday
Anyone else notice the night/sleep mini-theme? AWOKE, ABED, SUNUP, and NAP!

Somebody once quipped, "Writing about music is like dancing about architecture."

After I heard that, it occurred to me that that is what BEEs are doing in their waggle DANCE.

After the first few rounds, I almost went the way of Roberto Duran and said NO MAS before I took a NAP. Happy I kept jabbing at it so now I can focus on my YOGA MAT at SUN UP.

In the words of Ron Burgundy, YOU STAY CLASSY, DEL MAR.

Not sure about "misdirected clues," but I did find the puzzle delightfully (!!) challenging to finish. I loved it, worked hard at it, was happy with solving it, and thought I had really gotten my money's worth when it was finished. And solving it required a lot of crosses and back-ups, so I suppose "misdirected" was a piece of my delight. It felt very fair to me, just tough.

Very good puzzle.  I spent way too long figuring things out in the upper right and also the upper left.  In the end everything was fair and pretty clever.  But a "workout" for me.

At least Selsun Blue and yoga mats were gimmes (the latter having become a bit of an oreo lately).  Stay classy helped me straighten out the bottom right pretty quickly.

A fun, challenging exercise that took me longer than I'd have liked.

Did you know submariner and scuba diver are equally long?  That six AM and sunup have the same number of letters?  That sommeliers spelled with one M is as long as wine and beer snobs?  I didn't.  ;)

I think the only weak clue was "sts" for go around the block.  I may be missing something but hardly any streets do that?

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

"Stay classy, San Diego!" Isn't that how the Will Ferrell weatherman Ron Burgundy signs off? No scenes from Delmar that I recall, but might be time to watch that again. I don't recall laughing much when I saw it.

Such a sweetly beachy vibe, cabanas and scuba divers, or maybe taking a romantic walk with a single mom down by the bay at sunup, that would be a juicy play date wouldn't it? Better than putting on your Avias and taking your yoga mat to the gym in the annex next to the pool where these jerks are playing indoor canoe polo, or dating some beer snob who's such an aficionado he has his own ice bucket emblazoned with his name.  Elon, naturally.  Boring you to death as he discourses on the origins of wasabi mayo and why, in Japan, soy "weds" tastes together. Yada yada wawa wawa...maybe next time you'll pick a quiet type to dine with. Like mimes, for example. And while the ape starts bragging about the top speeds he's done in his boat, you ponder the question of whether a mime, if he were to become a novitiate in one of those abbeys with strict rules about speaking, would have to take a vow to yell, rather than a vow of silence. After a while, Elon notices you're not saying anything and asks what you're thinking. "I'm wondering whether any RBs have ever done a bee dance in the end zone," you reply. 

"Really?" he says.

"Really," you say. 

And that's the obit on that play date. 

Good puzzle! Esp. liked NO MAS for [Spanish uncle?]
I love the cover image you chose for this one! 🐊
Will I be the only solver who had --GA-ATS at 46A and entered MAGAHATS?

I'm uneasy with "Oh, brotherS, where arT THOU?" but I guess any kind of English is OK in crosswords.

I was also surprised at WASABI*MAYO* because my sleepy head let WASABI make me think we were talking Japanese food, not Hawaiian.

ENE by WSW

Is it too late to STAY CLASSY
To do a BEE DANCE on a YOGA MAT
To BOND with a ROMANTIC MIME
Or play CANOE POLO with a wombat?

Is it too late to WIN BY A MILE
To YELL “NO MAS” at TOP SPEED
To SCUBA DIVE at SUNUP
Our SAWS UP, our adages DEEP?

Is it too late for a SINGLE MOM
To shake this PO’ BOY AWaKE
AFICIANADO of “I DARE NOT”
Ready for a JUICY PLAY DATE?

Wonderfully juicy Friday puzzle.  Thanks, CC!
If you knew 11D without the crosses, I salute you.
This was my kind of puzzle: lots of wordplay, no rappers.

Me, pondering aloud: “What’s the word for that bee dance?” 

NOMAS was estupendo.
Could BEEDANCE be a [Hive mime]???
Fast and fun.

Brothers, where art thou? ABBEYS was a nice clue/answer combo. Alas, more clues made me sigh than smile today: there were too many unknowns for me, personally, to enjoy the puzzle. Names and abbreviations, combined with my never being on Mr Burnikel's wavelength, meant I needed loads of lookups: googling the trivia was my only way to generate crosses in places, with how unlike the constructor I apparently think about the world and words. Yesterday I needed no outside help, even though I think there were more proper nouns, and the gimmick made things harder- so probably my struggle today was all about the wavelength thing...

Is WAWA supposed to be what small children call water? I've just had this horrible vision of me breaking down completely over a Thursday puzzle where the gimmick would be: all the words are kid-speak 🤣. 

The grid also featured one of my most disliked kind of clue - direction from somewhere to somewhere. C'mon! I know for a US native that must be much easier than it will ever be for me, but still: meh.

Finally, seeing the E-word in the SW, even clued decently, did *not* make my day.
Lovely one from Zhou Qin Burnikel. Never disappoints.
I will never live down the fact that I, an advanced SCUBADIVER,, didn't get 15A. You could say it swam right over my head.
Probably more on the editor, but I don’t think I’ve once seen mustard on a po boy in Louisiana or SE Texas. Creole or otherwise. Just saying.
Of all the clue types I think [Word with x or y] is my top producer.  DEEP was the toehold,  after saying NO MAS to the NW stack, and pretty smooth sailing after that. Many thanks.

Got quite a bit of this one without lookups, but couldn’t quite get to then end without them. A little irked by NO HIT GAMES (I’ve never heard them called anything but “no hitters”) but yes, before someone points it out, in the crossword world it is technically correct. [sigh]

Small bone to pick: Chinese itself isn’t a single language. It’s a language family, similar to Romance languages. It would be similar to clueing “three, to a Romance language speaker” and the answer is tres.

Three in Mandarin is san. Three in Canto is saam. I’m sure there are plenty of other Chinese languages where this differs even further.

Great clues for ABBEYS [Oh, brothers, where art thou?], XMAS [Short day soon after the winter solstice] and especially, NO MAS [Spanish uncle?].

It was on the easier side, but it was so peppy and fresh that I found it a pleasure to solve.

Always glad to see C.C. - Typical tough Friday for me, but an enjoyable workout. Lots of nice 'aha' moments when I finally had enough crosses for something to dawn on me.

Eight debut answers, and a couple of them unfamiliar to me, but at least four of them quite familiar terms or phrases.  That's surprising and quite an impressive piece of construction.

Of course I have a puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

After perusing the puzzle a bit, I got a foot in the door at SELSUN Blue. From there it was a fun and pretty steady solve aside from the occasional clever misdirect. But I never cried uncle, even though it took me a while to get NO MAS. Who says a Friday puzzle can’t be fun? It can be done!

Zhouqin’s last Times puzzle came a week after Helene hit.  It was like the Twilight Zone here.  And what do I remember most?  Everybody was out of their homes helping everybody else.  “What can I do for you?”  “How can I help?”  “What do you need?”

What I learned was that beneath a world that might feel dark at times, there lies a well of light that feels infinite.  

This brings me solace and hope, and reminds me of Ghandi’s words: “When I despair, I remember that all through history the way of truth and love has always won.  There have been tyrants and murderers, and for a time, they can seem invincible, but in the end they always fall.  Think of it – always.”
Good n knotty! NOMAS brought to mind Roberto Duran, and “Day break” for NAP made me smile.
If I’ve learned any 1 lesson from my 4 or so years of working the NYT crossword, it’s that a 4 letter running shoe brand is NEVER Nike.

In a post yesterday, I mentioned "false friends," and today we have "AFICONADO," which, if not exactly "false," is a friend that you might think twice about lending your favorite sweater to.

That NW corner almost did me in. Sheer will power kept from running to the Rand-McNally Road Atlas, to get at least three sure squares.

Imagine me, in my bathrobe, so disheveled that my phone can't recognize me, sitting in my bathrobe at 5 AM and looking over the mini puzzle, wondering if AT EAT is yet another current phrase that I was ignorant of.
This one was really tricky for me, almost 40 minutes 😭 I was so confident about SESAMEMAYO as 1 across that it locked up my upper right hand corner until I finally gave in and read the blog.

Late week puzzles are such a 
source of joy for me.

Completing them is as bittersweet
as the final page of a beautiful book.

Finifugal. 
The *sigh* upon reaching the end
of something you’d love to stretch out
for much, much longer.

And a Burnikel Friday will always end that way.

Wishing everyone a Friday with some
unexpected, lovely surprise. 

Stay classy, San Diego.
Felt very fresh. I did think it was funny that it "balanced" interesting new answers and clues with, of course, baseball. Great puzzle, hope to see more from this constructor.
This was slow going for me until I looked at Google Maps to get the Nashville-Memphis thing, and then the rest fell into place.

Fun wordplay in this one, but I’m surprised there aren’t more bee snobs here to waggle their tongues and fingers at 28A. Maybe they were out all night doing the beer dance.

Nashville to Memphis direction: is your country getting the blues?

Fun puzzle like most Fridays have been lately. 

I did spend a considerable amount of time trying to understand the word ORELSE. Finally after solving I googled it and face palmed.
Started slow and then all of a sudden it was done.  But SAWS UP for "Sinks one's teeth into"?  I got it, but it still doesn't work.

Oh, by the way, English is not CC’s* first language.  I mention this to underscore my amazement over how well she has absorbed our language into her thinking, to the point where she has even mastered wordplay.

That mastery is on full display in this puzzle, and I, a lover of wordplay, was dazzled and delighted by its prevalence in the cluing.  My favorite was [Oh, brothers, where art thou?] for ABBEYS – never used before in any of the major crossword outlets, and solid gold.

As always with CC, the grid is so clean that peacefulness and relaxation wash over me when I look over the completed grid.  

The grid scintillates with spark as well. Of the 12 longest answers, seven are NYT answer debuts (including the entire NW stack), and three have only been used once previously.  Wow! Those debuts include a trio of answers that I can’t believe haven’t appeared before: SCUBA DIVER, WIN BY A MILE, and SINGLE MOM.

Your puzzle, CC, which abounded in riddle-cracking – what my brain loves – popped with pleasure for me.  Thank you so much for making it!

Re today’s mini:

Being the son in law of a Presbyterian minister came in handy today!  I giggled that the clue included “yes, there’s a word for this!”

The NW corner was the last to drop, and I had to walk away several times, but I finished without lookups or Googling, so I'll take that as a win.
Beautiful, smooth puzzle.

Very nice.

Thank you CC

Unlike many other New Orleanians, I’m not a stickler for food traditions, but 33 across stumped me for a while because I have never seen anyone put Creole (or any) mustard on one of these “food specialty” items.  Crystal hot sauce, yes, for sure.  I may try it, though!

Very happy with the PLAYDATES YOGAMATS cross that opened up the southwest for me.
I knew Memphis was by the river so west seemed likely as part of WSW so WASABI …. SCUBA….. and WINBY…. filled easily but the rest of the NW took me a while.

Oh, and I was unhappy when nohitters didn’t fit.
It fit the first time when I accidentally spelled it with three t’s :)
This is what I call a perfect puzzle full of delightful puns and word plays.

Most of this is great! Since I spent half my total time in the NE, I’ll say that DECO is not a common usage for Art Deco, and I doubt I’ve ever heard anyone say they were about to SAW(S) UP something. So one questionable clue and one questionable entry that happen to be near each other and crossing with other challenging but fun clued entries can make a tough corner.
ELON crossed with SINGLEMOM was good for a laugh.
great clues.  fun.  thank you.

Not an easy victory for me. I did not WIN BY A MILE. I got it done, but it was my second slowest Friday of the past year according to XW Stats. This could have something to do with the fact that I'm heading out on a road trip this morning and wanted to get done quickly to maintain the streak. Got stuck on SAWSUP for quite some time but managed to keep the streak alive, and now I'm ready to hit the road!

The NW was the last to fall for me. I really wanted 15A to be submariner.

WAWA was cute. That's what I used to call my sister Laura when we were little. Every time we went to the WAWA for gas it would make me giggle. Now she has kids of her own. Her oldest, Amelia, couldn't say her own name for quite a while, so she called herself Mia. Her little sister, on the other hand, calls her Ayaya. Both have become regular nicknames for her.

I loved today’s trifecta: great puzzle, excellent column, lively comments. 

Thank you, CC, Deb, and all commenters! Special credit so far to @Lewis, @johnezra, @Puzzlemucker, @Francis, and of course @Mike, plus the many wonderful regulars here today.
If I can’t have a theme, then CC is the constructor I would chose as her entries are alway fun and well clued.  I hope she doesn’t stay away as long again.
I was today years old when I learned that my dog isn't super excited to see me get home, she's just trying to alert me to a nearby nectar source.

Are we learning Mandarin or Cantonese?
Since it's CC, I have no complaints about learning the word for 'three,' but how do we pronounce it, and where might I use it???

I got derailed for a while because I thought an exfoliator should include soothing ALOE.  (More evidence of my skimpy knowledge of make-up and obsessive skin care; I earned every laugh line and wrinkle, crow's foot and deepened dimple--the only solution wd be a face-lift, but I'm not into pain.)
Oh, well.
And then came shampoo and TONER.  Could we just stop and talk about something else??!

If someone is 'Out,' might they have been AXED?
Finally, something I knew!  OLÉ!  Oops..

Oh, my....the old Scotch (ICE) BUCKET!  It crossed the 
Continental United States with us--before interstates!--multiple times.  Without a/c in the car, of course, it was a necessity.  
We were crossing the Great American Desert on a blistering August day, and Mom decided she would be more comfy without her bra.  After all, there wasn't a truck or a car in sight!  She had just disrobed when a car popped up out of an unseen wrinkle in the landscape.  Squawk!!!   We three kids nearly split our sides.

Great puzzle, fun time!

As a former resident of the Volunteer State, the locations of Nashville and Memphis are well known to me, and that immediately made me think that the "Poke bowl condiment" was going to be WASABI-something,
But I think that crushed WASABI peas would make a much better condiment than WASABI MAYO,
but that may be because I'm a MAYO-phobe.  Can't stand the stuff!

That slowed me down for a while, but didn't in any way interfere with my enjoyment of this fine Friday puzzle.
This crossword was so good I did it twice

Good morning!
The NE was a bear for me. I had to look up Weizenbock because I didn't know what it was. As it turns out, I am somewhat of a BEERSNOB. I toyed with "flap" before DECO as a 20's style. And 13D, I considered some sort of tea or maybe even a prison as a cooler. Laughed at myself when I got ICEBUCKET.
Ended up right around average time. Lots of good thinking. Now I need to apply that to work.

Too easy (at least for Friday), I feel. 

tc
I was hoping for a Robyn, but instead got a CC. That's worthy of a BEE DANCE. Buzz, buzz. Got a kick out of Cooler cousin/ICE BUCKET. Challenging.

The puzzle was tricky good fun for me. I was moving along last night  at a consistent pace until the NE corner. My brain just got stuck on certain answers and would not let go until I put my phone away and picked it up again this morning. 

1) I was sure the second word in 13D was jaCKET. You know, like the insulated "jackets" that go around cans and bottles of beer. Probably influenced by 12D.

2) 11A could only be epIc or SAGA or some kind of 4-letter bIo (those capital i's look like lower case L's) I'd never heard of.

3) 16A could only be some variation of flapper. Flap? Is that a thing? 

4) 25A I knew had to be SAWS + a proposition. I tried "at" and "on." UP didn't occur to me, probably because the word "sinking" brings to mind the downward motion of the saw. Yes, I get what SAWS UP means, so no one needs to explain it to me. Not saying it's wrong. I just personally don't love it as clued. 

5) 40A I mentally ran through the alphabet for the last letter (having no idea what 14D could be) and never connected ABED with Out until I finally finished the puzzle this morning and had the lightbulb moment.

All of this said, I put the puzzle to bed last night with only the NE corner unfinished, erased it all and started over this morning to finish pretty easily. I don't know if my brain is processing the answers while I sleep or if it's just seeing the puzzle with fresh eyes, but this often happens when I get stuck.

Took longer than usual, but zero lookups!

Ooh, I see CC’s byline and my heart races, I love her grids and haven’t seen her work here for a while (5 months according to Deb).
This one didn’t disappoint; chewy but informative. TIL among other things that there’s such a thing as CANOE POLO. Ditto the exotic (to me) condiments. I watch a chap on YouTube called BeardMeatsFood, a fellow Yorkshireman, who takes on food challenges. I love his US trips; besides the gargantuan serving sizes I’m always fascinated to learn about the myriad sauces and dressings there are. One day (maybe in four years+) I’ll do a foodie tour of the States and sample the delights of gravy, ranch etc. Not forgetting WASABI MAYO!

I was referred to this site by individuals outraged by my frustrated comments which, taken together, were a declaration of war against the makers and lovers of crossword puzzles. Now I see that the very thing that inflamed my passion against these puzzles is precisely what is most prized by those who love them. Nothing is "on the nose".  I could spend my life trying to figure out these clues and I still fail. I would go back to trying to counteract the effects of disease in babies who can't breathe, if I was not chronically ill myself. So, let me take up alcohol or narcotics. If I am successful at those I may qualify for a position in the Trump Administration.
52D is just ridiculous. Impossible to get without crosses. Starting to think every Spanish hint on the crosswords is done by people who have no idea about the language.

You know it's going to be a slog when the only entry you get on a cursory first pass is due to a childhood spent in front of the TV: SELSUN Blue.

Good puzzle.

Of course I enjoyed today’s puzzle, but given the current political situation it would have been nice if the answer to 64 across would have been different. I’m sure I’m not the only one who doesn’t want to see/type/hear the names of any political person anymore than we already have to. It’s just a suggestion! I’m not trying to cause trouble, but I’m simply stating my PerMinion (personal opinion). Have a Fantastic Friday my fellow NYTers and Namaste!!
Very fun puzzle today--not too puzzling, thankfully! Most of the clues were right in my wheelhouse, and those that weren't, were easily solved via crosses.

Thank you Zhouqin Burnikel for a challenging yet not impossibly cryptic crossword, which I was delighted to solve with no lookups and in a decent sub 30 min time. Lots of fun clues and clever puns. Mas por favor!
I haven’t finished yet, but I have to (playfully, lovingly) rage over 31D - if they use kayaks, it’s not CANOE POLO!

A big thank you to whoever it was that recommended "Ludwig" on BritBox. I watched the first episode last night, and loved it.

For everybody who missed that conversation, the show features a reclusive puzzle solver/constructor who finds himself suddenly (I'm studiously avoiding spoilers here) involved in a murder case. Sadly, only three episodes are available as yet, so I'm pacing myself.

A previous commenter called this puzzle "tricky fun," and I think that's a pretty good description, although I'd probably prepend "smooth" to that. It was smooth sailing for me except near the beginning, when I had SUBMARINER where SCUBA DIVER belonged. Funny how those both fit. Not being a Spanish speaker, I just assumed NOMAS (which I got from the crosses) translates to "uncles." I didn't get the joke until I read the column. Nice one! Thanks for the fun!
Am I the only one surprised that two clues ended in “up” (3D and 25A)? I thought that was against the crossword rules?

Nice, gentle Friday puzzle. Done in 20 minutes, which for me is very quick for a Friday.

Would have been quicker, but I first wrote BASTA for "Spanish uncle?". And once that became NOMAS, I decided that a NOD rather than a BOW was a "Show of respect".

OK, time to walk to the local WAWA and get a hoagie. No POBOYs available.

Expecting sunshine and almost 80F tomorrow. Sounds like a marvelous day for a BEEDANCE. I wonder if Van Morrison would agree.

A lovely puzzle.  [Spanish uncle?] was just brilliant.  Also loved [Day break].  [Append] next to [Append].  And AWOKE above ABED.

I don't completely agree with Deb regarding "no junk in the grid at all" but I'll happily tolerate WSW and ENE for a puzzle of this caliber.  

I had "one hitter" at first for 61A, which led to AREO___ for [Entertainment centers] and led my mind immediately into the gutter.  I hope I never have to grow up.

Wow, some SERIOUSLY clunky fill in this one. SAWSUP we might forgive, but when it's in the same puzzle as NO HIT GAMES (vs. the actual term NO HITTER) I lose patience. 

Also, as a lifelong gulf coast resident, I inform you that creole mustard is not really a common topping on po-boys. 

Roast beef poboys will be dressed with a gravy, not a mustard. 

Fried seafood examples (oyster, shrimp, catfish) will have remoulade if you're lucky, or simple mayo in less interesting locations. 

Catfish probably follows the seafood standard, but sometimes has a slaw as a topping. 

And boudin po boys -- my favorite -- probably boast a Louisiana hot sauce, not a mustard (tourists pick Tabasco; locals will pick Crystal). 

Generally, that's just a long way of saying it's an example of someone not really knowing the subject, and mashing together something that might get answered right, but isn't actually real. Sadly, that kind of thing is endemic in crosswords.

I AWOKE today in a bit of a mood... and not a good one. There are good reasons for it and also I soon went into AFib again, so bit of a rough day so far. But this puzzle and many of the comments brought a measure or two of joy into the day. And I'm so grateful for it! 

BEEDANCE itself makes me strangely happy. DANCE, little BEEs, DANCE! 

Or more eloquently by Emily Dickinson

In the name of the Bee —
And of the Butterfly —
And of the Breeze — Amen!

ICEBUCKET reminded me of the ice bucket challenge from a few years back to raise funds to fight ALS.... My favorite of which is shown here: https://youtu.be/Ty6-Ug1wk-0?si=riW65sehMwm6BnTF Sir Patrick Stewart never needs to be told to STAYCLASSY. He was born classy!

Fun but a little quick for a Friday for me. What else is new?

Back to the archives!
Adding BEE DANCE to "aglet" as puzzle answers I know from watching Phineas and Ferb. https://youtu.be/_lqNlE3ywQs?feature=shared
Has anyone but me found recent Friday puzzles to be way easier than Thursday puzzles?

I liked the puzzle and appreciated lots of witty clues (like others have noted SINGLEMOM and ELON crossing gave me a chuckle). 

I really struggled with “NO HIT GAMES”….Nolan Ryan had a legendary 7 NO HITTERS.
Another great Friday puzzle from one of the best constructors in the game.
Great puzzle! Thrilled to see my Alma mater ELON getting some recognition!
Well I was happy to finish this with no help. Was tempted to check words at first but didn’t. Thank you, Zhouqin Burnikel, Deb and commenters. Have a great weekend!

userLocation: Boston suburbs and south coast MA
commentBody:
Whoa! Lots of action here today for this outstanding puzzle, so much so that I can’t get through all the comments —a long way of saying I may be repeating something that’s already been discussed. 

But TIL the Spanish word for amateur (French is my romance language 🤓). Very interesting in its contrast to the use in the English language… Does that make it a “false friend?” Or is there another term for this?
Tough but fair.
50A - living in San Diego finally pays off.
Terrific Friday puzzle. I didn’t find it as “easy” as some did, but it did feel accessible. I will admit to getting a couple of Tricky Clues from Deb.

Proper Friday.  Great cluing, many “aha!” Moments.  Can’t really see any weak spots in the whole grid.  Nicely done.  TIL what aficionado really means.  Clever misdirect on what typically shows up as “ole” - liked that.
Zhouqin stayed classy for a Friday challenge...well done!! Come back for another play date soon.

Terrific puzzle! Very smart, very challenging.

I think, though, that "thou" is singular. The plural would be "ye."

Wow!  I did this puzzle in 15 minutes.  My Friday average is 35 min!!
And no lookups, except I was stuck.  All filled in, no happy music.  Time to read the column.

Had AWaKE and AxED  instead of AWOKE and ABED.  I got the ABED from the column and then the SNOBS part fit. 

So it was fast, but I think I was just on the right wavelength.  I started the puzzle thinking I'd make a pass through, then let the brain cells mull while I cook dinner.  Come back and finish later.....

Some background first. In 1980, Panamanian boxer Roberto Durán fought American Sugar Ray Leonard for the welterweight championship of the world.  At some point in this fight, Durán was famously reported to have said "No más," and the fight was stopped in favor of Leonard.  Whether he actually said those words is up for debate, but the supposed words uttered to end the fight became very well known.

In English, of course, an uncle is the brother of one of your parents, or even the husband of your parent's sister.  This is not how "No más" is meant to equate to "uncle" in English.  That would indeed make no sense.

But another use of the word comes from the playground.  When a fight breaks out between two small children, usually boys, the one with the upper hand says to the other, "Say 'uncle'."  If the other does, it means he quits.  
 
That's how "uncle" comes to mean "No más," and it's perfectly normal in American English.  (The question mark, as you know, is how you know they just don't want the Spanish word for your parent's brother.)

Let me ask you this:

I assume by your "MD" that you are a medical doctor.

Is *everything* you say, what you tell you patients, what you discuss with other doctors, absolutely correct beyond any possible objection?

Probably not.  I taught General and Physical Chemistry for years, and virtually every single thing I said in class had unspoken qualifications to it.  I knew about them, but to expose all that complexity to the students at that time would have served no good purpose.

So, yes, there are two meanings to the word.  Maybe more.  Most words have more than one meaning.  And not every single one of well over a hundred answers are going to be utterly perfect.

For me it's been somewhat rare-ish since I was diagnosed... but lately it's been increasing quite a bit to a noticeable and quite inconvenient degree. 

It's one of the few things that I can't work through. I'll work through almost anything ("You've got no arms left..."   "It's just a flesh wound!") but AFib stops me completely, until my heart is back to normal.

It's an annoyance, but it is also dangerous. It greatly increases one's risk for a stroke. This is managed by going on a blood thinner to try to prevent stroke.
